item.title: Iran Frees Americans, Including Jason Rezaian, in Prisoner Swap
item.description: Word of the exchange came just before longstanding economic sanctions on Iran were lifted under terms of the historic nuclear deal reached in July.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERBRINK and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Zoeann Murphy/The Washington Post, via Reuters

item.title: Iran Complies With Nuclear Deal; Sanctions Are Lifted
item.description: Iran has shipped most of its nuclear fuel out of the country, destroyed the innards of a plutonium-producing reactor and mothballed more than 12,000 centrifuges.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: From left, Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister; Yukiya Amano, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency; and Federica Mogherini, the European Union’s high representative for foreign affairs and security policy, at the meeting in Vienna.

item.title: Patriots 27, Chiefs 20: Patriots Methodically Clear First Hurdle
item.description: Bill Belichick, the New England coach, and his quarterback Tom Brady have now won 22 postseason games.
item.dc:creator: BILL PENNINGTON
item.media:credit: Greg M. Cooper/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Patriots quarterback Tom Brady diving for a touchdown in the second quarter.

item.title: Virginia Man Is Accused of Trying to Join ISIS; Another Is Charged With Helping Him
item.description: The Justice Department said that one of the men was arrested at an airport, where he planned to begin a journey to Syria to fight with ISIS, and that the other assisted him.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Federal Emergency Is Declared in Flint Over Contaminated Water
item.description: President Obama cleared the way for federal aid for Flint, Mich., which is struggling with a drinking water crisis.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:credit: Jake May/The Flint Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Terra Castro, who lives in St. Clair Shores, Mich., wipes away tears during a break from dropping off more than 500 cases of bottled water in Flint.

item.title: Before Debris Collapse in China, Safety Fears Were Discussed
item.description: China’s industrial safety record has improved in recent years, but the ruling Communist Party still struggles to impose accountability on local bureaucrats.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Firefighters searched for survivors amid the debris of destroyed buildings in Shenzhen, China, on Dec. 21.

item.title: New Guidelines Nudge Doctors on Giving Patients Access to Medical Records
item.description: In new guidelines, the Obama administration says doctors and hospitals cannot require patients to state a reason for requesting their records, and cannot deny access out of a general concern that patients might be upset by the information.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT PEAR
item.media:credit: Melissa Golden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christopher S. Moore with his son, Oliver, 4, who has a rare genetic disorder. Mr. Moore said he had difficulty getting Oliver’s full medical records.

item.title: Huffington Post Waited to Report U.S.-Iran Prisoner-Swap Negotiations
item.description: The news organization said it chose not to run an article on the negotiations over a prisoner exchange that included a Washington Post reporter, though it learned about the talks last fall.
item.dc:creator: SYDNEY EMBER
item.media:description: The wife of Saeed Abedini holding a necklace with a photograph of her husband, a pastor who was arrested in Iran in 2012. Iran announced on Saturday that it had released four Iranian-Americans, including Mr. Abedini, as part of a prisoner exchange with the United States.

item.title: Standoff in Oregon Attracts Supporters Bearing Disparate Grievances
item.description: As the protest at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge has dragged on, it has become a magnet of sorts, attracting strands of diverse conservative movements from across the country.
item.dc:creator: ALAN FEUER
item.media:description: Activists at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon gathered around a fire last week. Various factions of the so-called Patriot movement have joined the occupation.

item.title: David Bowie: Invisible New Yorker
item.description: Despite being a rock legend, the musician was an apparition in Manhattan, able to walk the city streets unrecognized.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN KURUTZ
item.media:credit: Masayoshi Sukita, via Morrison Hotel Gallery
item.media:description: David Bowie in 1989. He lived in New York City for more than 20 years.

item.title: In Tehran, Iranians Play Down Milestone
item.description: The low-key reception for the expected lifting of sanctions reflects multiple disappointments and broken promises.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Tehran’s Grand Bazaar on Saturday. International sanctions on Iran related to its nuclear activities were expected to be lifted soon.

item.title: What Donald Trump’s Plaza Deal Reveals About His White House Bid
item.description: The mogul’s purchase of the Plaza Hotel in 1988 offers insight into the methods and thinking of a deal maker turned presidential candidate.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SEGAL
item.media:description: “To me the Plaza was like a great painting,” Donald Trump said of the hotel he agreed to buy in 1988 and later lost in bankruptcy. “It wasn’t purely about the bottom line.”

item.title: Deadly Standoff Leaves Burkina Faso Stunned
item.description: Gunfire raged through the night as armed forces from Burkina Faso, assisted by French and American forces, stormed the popular downtown area where attackers had set off explosives.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Rescue workers carrying a body from the Splendid Hotel in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Saturday.

item.title: Q. and A.: What Happens Now That Sanctions Are Lifted?
item.description: The most immediate benefit to Iran will be access to roughly $100 billion of its own money, but the United States still has a raft of sanctions in place.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iran Complies With Nuclear Deal; Sanctions Are Lifted
item.description: Iran has shipped most of its nuclear fuel out of the country, destroyed the innards of a plutonium-producing reactor and mothballed more than 12,000 centrifuges.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Zoeann Murphy/The Washington Post, via Reuters

item.title: Cardinals and Packers in an N.F.C. Showdown
item.description: Highlights, scores and analysis from Arizona.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Singer’s Apology for Waving Taiwan Flag Stirs Backlash of Its Own
item.description: The videotaped apology from the singer, Chou Tzu-yu, with the K-pop band Twice, was addressed in a victory speech by Taiwan’s president-elect.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Ad of the Week: Bernie Sanders’s Vision Makes Hillary Clinton Camp See Red
item.description: Hillary Clinton’s campaign denounced an ad for Bernie Sanders in Iowa and New Hampshire, calling it a negative attack — a characterization Mr. Sanders’s team denied.
item.dc:creator: NICK CORASANITI

item.title: Clinton Campaign Underestimated Sanders Strengths, Allies Say
item.description: Advisers to Mrs. Clinton, including the former president Bill Clinton, believe that her campaign made serious miscalculations by failing to undercut Mr. Sanders’s message early in the race.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK HEALY
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton at a campaign event in Sioux City this month.

item.title: Profiles of Saeed Abedini, Amir Hekmat and Jason Rezaian
item.description: Saeed Abedini, Amir Hekmat and Jason Rezaian are among the American citizens who have been held in Iran.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Jason Rezaian, Saeed Abedini and Amir Hekmati
